title: Quiz 5: ANS, Respiratory & GIT Drugs
description: Assess your understanding of drugs affecting the Autonomic Nervous System, Respiratory System (Asthma/Allergy), and Gastrointestinal Tract (Ulcers/Emesis) (Units 14-15).

questions.question: Match the Adrenergic Receptor with its primary physiological effect when stimulated:

pairs.right: Increased heart rate and myocardial contraction
Inhibition of insulin secretion (and negative feedback)

questions.explanation: Alpha-1 affects vessels (constriction); Beta-1 affects the Heart (1 heart); Beta-2 affects Lungs (2 lungs); Alpha-2 is regulatory.

questions.question: What is the most common side effect associated with the use of Atropine Sulfate (a parasympatholytic)?
questions.explanation: Atropine blocks parasympathetic impulses, stopping secretions (dry mouth), relaxing smooth muscle (constipation), and increasing heart rate.

questions.question: Which of the following are important nursing considerations for a patient receiving Theophylline/Aminophylline? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Monitor for signs of toxicity (anorexia, nausea, restlessness)
Administer IV rapid bolus to ensure quick action
Administer oral medication with meals to avoid gastric pain
Encourage fluid intake to liquefy secretions
Encourage caffeine intake to potentiate effect

questions.explanation: Theophylline causes GI upset (take with food) and has a narrow therapeutic window. Rapid IV administration causes hypotension/arrhythmia (Give slowly). Caffeine increases toxicity risk.
questions.hint: Think about the drug's similarity to caffeine (Xanthine derivative).

questions.question: Antihistamines used for allergies block ___BLANK___ receptors, while drugs used for peptic ulcers (like Ranitidine) block ___BLANK___ receptors.
questions.explanation: H1 blockers treat allergy/inflammation. H2 blockers reduce gastric acid secretion.
questions.hint: Number 1 is for allergy, Number 2 is for the stomach.

questions.question: Review the Antacid Interaction Table below. When should a patient typically take an antacid relative to other medications or meals?

richContent.content:
DrugInteraction with Antacids
TetracyclineDecreased absorption
IronDecreased absorption
DigoxinDecreased absorption

options.text: 1 hour before or 2-3 hours after meals/medications

questions.explanation: Antacids interfere with the absorption of many drugs. They are generally best taken 1-3 hours after meals and at bedtime, separated from other oral meds.
questions.hint: Give the stomach time to empty or coat.

questions.question: Metoclopramide (Pramin) is safe to use in patients with suspected intestinal obstruction.
questions.explanation: False. Metoclopramide is a prokinetic agent that stimulates motility. Using it during an obstruction could cause perforation or severe injury.

questions.question: Which drug is a Proton Pump Inhibitor (PPI) used to eradicate H. pylori and treat GERD?
questions.explanation: Omeprazole inhibits the acid (proton) pump. Ranitidine is an H2 blocker. Maalox is an antacid.

questions.question: What is the primary emergency drug used for cardiac arrest and anaphylactic shock due to its ability to stimulate Alpha, Beta-1, and Beta-2 receptors?
questions.explanation: Epinephrine (Adrenaline) is the drug of choice for anaphylaxis and cardiac arrest due to its potent vasoconstrictive and bronchodilating effects.
questions.hint: Naturally produced by the adrenal medulla.

questions.question: Which of the following are contraindications for the use of Atropine? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Atropine dilates pupils (bad for glaucoma), increases heart rate (bad for tachycardia), and relaxes bladder muscle (bad for prostate retention). It IS used to TREAT bradycardia.

questions.question: A patient takes a First-Generation Antihistamine (e.g., Promethazine/Phenergan). What is the most critical safety instruction?

options.text: Do not drive or operate heavy machinery due to sedation.

questions.explanation: First-generation H1 blockers cross the blood-brain barrier and cause significant sedation/drowsiness.

questions.question: Arrange the steps for managing an Epinephrine IV infusion:

items.text: Dilute to correct concentration (1:1000 for SC, 1:10,000 for IV)
Use a micro-drip or infusion pump
Monitor BP and Pulse constantly during infusion

questions.explanation: Correct dilution is critical first. Precision equipment is needed. Vital signs must be monitored during the infusion. Site checks prevent necrosis.

questions.question: Match the specific drug to its therapeutic classification:
questions.explanation: Salbutamol stimulates beta-2 receptors. Scopolamine blocks acetylcholine. Ranitidine blocks histamine-2. Metoclopramide blocks dopamine in the CTZ.
questions.hint: Focus on the body system: Lungs, Brain/Gut, Stomach, Gut.

questions.question: What is the specific action of 'Omeprazole' that makes it effective for ulcers?

options.text: It blocks the proton pump, inhibiting acid formation.
It blocks histamine at H2 receptors.

questions.explanation: Omeprazole binds to the hydrogen-potassium ATPase (proton pump) to block the final step of gastric acid formation.

questions.question: Paradoxical excitation (restlessness, insomnia) can occur with Antihistamines, especially in children and the elderly.
questions.explanation: True. While sedation is common, children and the elderly may experience the opposite effect (excitation/agitation) with antihistamines.
questions.hint: The opposite of what you expect.

questions.question: What is the term for the drug-induced movement disorders (e.g., tremors, muscle rigidity) that can occur as a side effect of Metoclopramide?
questions.explanation: Metoclopramide blocks dopamine, which can cause extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) similar to antipsychotic drugs.

questions.question: Which condition is a contraindication for the use of Epinephrine (Adrenaline)?
questions.explanation: Epinephrine causes pupil dilation (mydriasis), which can dangerously increase intraocular pressure in narrow-angle glaucoma.
questions.hint: It relates to pressure in the eye.

questions.question: Which of the following side effects are associated with the use of Aluminum-containing antacids? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Aluminum causes constipation. Magnesium causes diarrhea. Aluminum binds phosphate.

questions.question: The medication ___BLANK___ is used for motion sickness and should be taken 30 minutes before travel.
questions.explanation: Promethazine (Phenergan) or Scopolamine are commonly used for motion sickness prophylaxis.

questions.question: When administering a bronchodilator (e.g., Ventolin) and a corticosteroid inhaler, what is the correct order?

options.text: Bronchodilator first, wait 5 mins, then Corticosteroid

questions.explanation: The bronchodilator opens the airways first, allowing the corticosteroid to penetrate deeper into the lungs.
questions.hint: Open the door before you walk through.

questions.question: What is the primary action of Glycerin Suppositories?

options.text: Stimulate peristalsis by irritating the rectal mucosa
Soften stool by lowering surface tension

questions.explanation: Glycerin promotes defecation by local irritation of the rectal mucosa and hyperosmotic action (drawing water).
questions.hint: It works locally in the rectum.
